a.title: Deskside Chat with Dr. Spence
a.style: color: rgb(134, 0, 0); text-decoration-line: underline; font-family: Tahoma, Verdana, Arial, Helvetica; font-size: 13.3333px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);

img.alt: Watch Now: Deskside with Dr. Spence
img.title: Watch Now: Deskside with Dr. Spence
img.style: float: right; width: 168px; height: 168px; margin-bottom: 5px; margin-left: 10px;

a.title: Haga clic aquí para ver este mensaje en español

p.a: Haga clic aquí para ver este mensaje en español

div.p: We hope the transition to the Emergency Learning Plan (ELP) is going as smoothly as possible.

As a reminder, students are expected to submit one assignment per week per course through the end of the school year. Parents with elementary school students should work with the teacher or school administrator to address questions related to the Emergency Learning Plan work submissions. For parents of students in middle and high school, please be aware that you can keep track of your child’s work submissions during the ELP by logging into the ParentVUE gradebook.
If you have any questions, please reach out to the principal at your child’s school. Technical issues can be addressed through our Customer Support Center at (757) 263-1111.

With the third marking period ending this past Friday, April 24, report cards will be available for access via ParentVUE by the close of the day Wednesday, April 29. Instructions for how to access this information is provided on our website.

This past Saturday, April 25, the Department of Technology sent emails to all parents who do not currently have a ParentVUE account. Information in that email will assist parents in establishing an account. In the event you are unable to access the report card via ParentVUE and would like to receive the information, please contact the school via email. Again, our Customer Support Center is available at (757) 263-1111 between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday through Friday.
Thank you for your support of Virginia Beach City Public Schools.

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_0","title":"April 23 Update","content":"
Good evening VBCPS families-\n
While I’m sure this Spring Break wasn’t anything like what you imagined when you initially marked it on the calendar back in September, I do hope you were able to take a couple of deep breaths last week and at least enjoy some nice weather. \n
As the Continuity of Learning Plan comes to an end tomorrow, I would like to thank you, again, for all the understanding and love you’ve sent our way as we worked though those early stages of shaping an education for your children under these remarkable circumstances. Even while facing all the stressors of a global health pandemic, learning has continued. You need only search #VBAlwaysLearning on social media to witness the thousands of ways our community has stepped up to maintaining what’s important: the future of our children.\n
And the learning will continue. Monday marks the start of our Emergency Learning Plan (ELP), which will take us through the end of the academic year. I’m proud to say that thanks to some long days, rigorous professional development sessions and ongoing collaboration with principals and peers, our educators are ready for this next phase.\n
Monday Preparation\n
If you’ve not had a chance to do so yet, please review the ELP for details about curriculum, learning expectations and scheduling. Please also refer to my April 21 update, where I go into considerable depth regarding the creation and implementation of this plan.\n
As a reminder, our teachers will continue to use Mondays as professional learning days, while students are encouraged to use them as days to unplug and get active, aka Moving Mondays. Tuesdays through Fridays will be instructional days, when teachers will hold office hours, provide feedback on assignments and offer opportunities to extend learning. \n
Student Work Expectations\n
To be very clear, students must continue to submit work in order to be promoted to the next grade level or to receive credit for the high school courses they may be taking. That said, we will not be grading student work during the ELP. Why? Grading should reflect teaching and subsequent learning, not circumstances beyond a child’s control. Without dedicated time in our classrooms and daily access to all of the services that a school and the division offer, our students would be graded based on their access to technology, the internet, food and housing, a stable home environment, their ableism and the language they speak, but not on their ability to learn. The Virginia Department of Education also does not recommend grading at this time. \n
More details on grading, broken down by grade level, are on our ELP website and in Schoology. Parents can utilize ParentVue to track whether their child is submitting their required assignments each week. If a parent needs help accessing ParentVue, they can call the Customer Support Center at (757)263-1111.\n
As I’ve explained previously, this plan is designed to address essential standards, while at the same time giving serious consideration to equity and access, so that we provide learning experiences for all students, regardless of circumstances.\n
Your child’s teachers will remain flexible, supportive and understanding throughout these remaining weeks of the school year, ensuring all students continue to engage in learning and complete the required assignments to be successful the following year.\n
Access to Technology\n
If teachers or students are having any issues with their school-issued devices, they should first contact the Customer Support Center at (757) 263-1111. A trained technician will make every attempt to resolve the issue over the phone. If that’s not possible, we will coordinate a time to exchange the malfunctioning device for another like device. As we communicated previously, starting next week our device exchange program will continue to be available daily (Monday through Friday, 9 a.m.-4 p.m.) at a central location. Please call the Customer Support Center to make an appointment. If families have transportation concerns, they should let the technician know so that alternate arrangements can be made.\n
Food Service\n
Food service hours and locations have returned to their pre-Spring Break schedule of Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. - noon. A list of distribution sites is available at VBSchools.com.\n
Staying Healthy\n
Please continue to follow the CDC guidelines for keeping safe and minimizing the spread of COVID-19. “Social distancing” means staying out of crowded places, avoiding group gatherings, and maintaining a distance of 6 feet from others whenever possible. Medical questions may be directed to the VDH Hotline: 877-275-8343 (877-ASK-VDH3).\n
My Deskside Chats will continue as we implement the ELP. I will have a new one for you every Thursday, and you can submit questions for me to answer here. Please continue to follow our website, www.vbschools.com/COVID19, and marvel at all the wonderous things our VBCPS family is up to via #VBAlwaysLearning on our social media channels. Our buildings may be closed, but school is very much still in session. \n
Please take care yourself and your family.\n
Aaron Spence, Ed.D.
\nSuperintendent\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_1","title":"April 22 Update","content":"
Haga clic aquí para ver este mensaje en español\n
Dear VBCPS families-\n
We hope that Spring Break provided you with some greatly deserved down time and a chance to take a few deep breaths. We have an update and a couple of reminders to start off this week. \n
In order to balance the health and safety needs of VBCPS staff, yet continue to provide the best service to students, teachers and families, we will be consolidating the hotspot distribution and device exchange program for VBCPS issued laptops and Chromebooks. Beginning April 27, this exchange program will be available only at the Plaza Annex building, 641 Carriage Hill Rd, Virginia Beach. The hours of the exchange program are 9 a.m.-4 p.m., Monday through Friday, by appointment only. The front parking lot of the Plaza Annex building is under construction for the next few weeks, so please use the entrance for Brookwood Elementary School to access Plaza Annex. \n
If teachers or students are having any issues with their device, they should first contact the Customer Support Center at (757) 263-1111. Trained technicians will make every attempt to resolve the issue over the phone. If that’s not possible, we’ll coordinate a time to exchange the malfunctioning device for another like device. If students have transportation concerns getting to the Plaza Annex building, they should let the Customer Support Center know and we will make alternate arrangements. \n
Also, food service hours and locations have returned to their pre-Spring Break schedule of Monday through Friday, 9 a.m. - noon. A list of distribution sites is available at VBSchools.com. \n
Lastly, please check our website, VBSchools.com/covid19, for the latest Deskside Chat with Superintendent Dr. Aaron Spence where he addresses why we chose not to grade assignments for credit moving into the fourth marking period. \n
Dr. Spence will be sending a letter and a new Deskside Chat this Thursday with more information and a reminder about the Emergency Learning Plan that begins Monday, April 27. \n
Thank you for your support of Virginia Beach City Public Schools.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_2","title":"April 21 Update","content":"
\n
Dear VBCPS families-\n
Thank you again for your patience and support as we have worked through these past couple of weeks to make sure students are fed and engaged in their learning. And again, I cannot tell you how reassuring it is to see and hear all the positivity via email and through social media during this closure. I love seeing all of us work through this together, even though things feel a little uncertain right now. So I want to start by saying that I share your concerns. I feel your frustrations. That’s because in my family, we are dealing with many of the same challenges you are. I have six children in my house, all in various stages of their education from elementary school to high school to those who’ve been sent home from their universities.\n
Like everyone else, we’re also feeling stress during this health crisis. And we are worried by all of the unknowns. When will this end? When will things get back to normal and what will that look like? And even how do I teach my kid about division or magnets or even get him to sit still in front of a computer long enough to finish his work?\n
I’ve heard from many of you, and I recognize that one of the results of this pandemic is that overnight, many of us became first-year teachers. And that's tough, because we aren’t all teachers. We have our own work and other issues to attend to, yet we still want to make sure our children have everything they need.\n
We worry about our own limitations with these learning expectations and about what this means for our children.\n
So, I hear you. And the most important thing I want to say to you is that being a full-time teacher while parenting and dealing with your own stressors at home is not our expectation.\n
Meals will be provided on weekdays from 9 a.m. – noon. \n
All school food distribution sites also will be preparing weekend breakfast and lunch meals for students to take home each Friday. \n
And we certainly don’t want to add more to our kids’ own concerns about what they see going on around them.\n
But we also want to value and honor our kids experiences around school. I feel our students’ hearts break when they can't hang out with their friends, when they can't participate in morning meetings, when prom is canceled, or when graduation ceremonies are uncertain.\n
At this point, while some things are out of my control, I hope you’ll know that my priorities for your children remain the same they have always been: I want to make sure they know they are loved and cared for, and I want to try to keep them engaged in learning.\n
Which brings me to this week’s news.\n
Continuity of Learning Plan Shifts to Emergency Learning Plan\n
In response to Governor Northam’s executive order prompting the extended closure of schools for the rest of the school year, and with guidance from the Virginia Department of Education, Virginia Beach City Public Schools will shift to the  VBCPS 2019-2020 Emergency Learning Plan, effective April 27.\n
This plan is designed to address essential standards, while at the same time giving serious consideration to equity and access, so that we provide learning experiences for all students.\n
By implementing this emergency learning plan, we will be able to continue to provide much of what was provided during our Continuity of Learning Plan, while ensuring students are being provided learning that is aligned to the most essential standards and skills to prepare students for promotion to the next grade level.\n
We understand that every child’s circumstances are different. Some parents may desire more homework and instruction while others want less. We also understand our teachers have their own families in their care, and that the impact of the economy is an additional source of stress for all of us. Therefore, to be sensitive and respectful to all, we will focus academic instruction on just these essential standards.\n
Your child’s teachers will remain flexible, supportive and understanding during these difficult times to ensure all students can continue to engage in learning and complete the required assignments to be successful the following year.\n
A New Schedule\n
This Emergency Learning Plan instructional schedule was developed with the intention to provide a consistent, predictable schedule that supports families as they support their students’ learning. The schedule also enables educators to support their own families and ensure their own health and wellness. An emphasis has been placed on allowing students to access learning opportunities at a time that best meets their needs. It also provides adequate time for teachers to communicate and connect with students on a consistent basis, especially with those students who are not submitting assignments or those not checking in on the digital platforms. Finally, this schedule recognizes the importance of students maintaining a connection to the arts and personal health and wellness. \n
Teachers will use Mondays as professional learning days, taking the time to plan lessons for the week, give feedback to students on submitted work, and connect with students who have not submitted work or logged in to digital platforms. For students, these will be called Moving Mondays. It’s an opportunity for students to unplug from devices and to engage in activities of choice, such as journaling, exercising, playing instruments, completing assignments and planning for the week. \n
Tuesdays through Fridays will be instructional days, when teachers will hold office hours, provide feedback on assignments and offer opportunities to extend learning. Students can view recordings of the lessons provided by their teachers, work on assignments, practice their music, exercise and journal. \n
Again, this schedule will take effect April 27. \n
Grading\n
As a reminder, for the third marking period, grades will be calculated based on work that was due on or before March 13. \n
For secondary students, they can continue to improve their grade by completing missing assignments that they have been communicating with their teacher about. \n
For the Emergency Learning Period, based on the recommendations of the Virginia Department of Education Task Force, there will not be any grading for students on any level. While this may be surprising to some, again, these are different times, and they require different thinking. \n
Students who were on track to be promoted to the next grade level, who consistently demonstrated the necessary skills and concepts to be successful in the next grade level during the first, second and third marking periods, and who engage regularly in the Emergency Learning Plan and turn in assignments during the fourth marking period, which ends June 12, will be promoted to the next grade level. \n
As I have said before, seniors who were on track to graduate as of March 13, will graduate. That’s why it’s so important for our seniors to make sure they are working with their teachers during this third marking period to ensure their grades are on track for graduation and that they continue to demonstrate they are learning by completing assigned work for the remainder of the year. Doing so will allow us to grant our seniors the credits needed to graduate. \n
If your child is not on track, we will do everything possible to get them where they need to be so they can graduate with the Class of 2020. \n
More details on grading, broken down by grade level, is on our Emergency Learning Plan website and in Schoology. \n
I want to assure you that our VBCPS staff is committed to being a resource to you and your students during this incredible time. Please let our administrators and school counselors know how we can support you and your children. \n
Spring Break and Food Service\n
Our school and administrative buildings will be closed during Spring Break, April 13-17. Our Department of Technology help desk hotline will not be answered during this time. \n
However, meals will be available at the 41 school and neighborhood distribution sites during the following modified schedule: \n
Monday: 9 a.m.-noon, breakfast and lunch meals for Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday will be available\n
Tuesday: no service\n
Wednesday: no service\n
Thursday: 9 a.m.-noon, breakfast and lunch meals for Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday will be available\n
The daily distribution schedule will resume the Monday after Spring Break, April 20. \n
Advanced Placement (AP) Exams\n
The College Board has announced that students will be able to take their AP exams online at home and has provided preparation materials that AP teachers have access to. It is our expectation that AP teachers continue to work with their students to prepare them for these exams. Yesterday, all high schools shared more detailed information regarding AP exams with the families of students currently enrolled in an AP class. Please review that information and reach out to your AP teacher if you have questions. \n
Online Registration \n
VBCPS is pleased to offer online registration to all schools within the division. If you have a child that will attend as a new student to VBCPS for the 2019-2020 school year, you are eligible to begin registration online. \n
In order to access Online Registration, you must have an active ParentVUE account. To create an account for Online Registration, please click the button \"More Options,\" select \"Create a New Account,\" and follow the prompts. \n
Census 2020\n
Please don’t forget to fill out your census form, either by mail, by phone or online. Census results help determine how money is allocated for grants that support teachers and special education. Data collected from the census also helps communities respond to natural disasters and secure funding for hospitals and fire departments. \n
 Staying Healthy\n
We encourage your family to follow the CDC guidelines for keeping safe and minimizing the spread of COVID-19. “Social distancing” means staying out of crowded places, avoiding group gatherings, and maintaining a distance of 6 feet from others whenever possible. Medical questions may be directed to the VDH Hotline: 877-275-8343 (877-ASK-VDH3). \n
All of this information and more is shared and updated on our website, www.vbschools.com/COVID19. I also encourage you to watch my Deskside Chats, closed- captioned videos shared every Tuesday and Thursday on YouTube, where I provide updates and answer a few questions. Feel free to submit your questions here. Be sure to follow #VBAlwaysLearning on social media for a look at what our teachers and students have been up to. \n
Thank you for your patience and flexibility, and as always, thank you for your support of Virginia Beach City Public Schools. \n
Aaron Spence, Ed.D. 
\nSuperintendent\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_3","title":"April 3 Update","content":"
Good evening VBCPS families-\n
Once again, I want to start this week’s message with gratitude for your patience and support as we continue to shape what the rest of the school year will look like. While I know these emails are long, it’s my intention to be as concise as I can while still sharing the work of the school division during this extended closure. Hopefully, we’ll be able to make them a little shorter every week as we figure out where all those moving parts are going to fit. In the meantime, if you prefer, know that this information is shared and updated on our website, www.vbschools.com/COVID19. I also encourage you to watch my Deskside Chats, closed- captioned videos shared every Tuesday and Thursday on YouTube, where I provide updates and tackle a few questions. Feel free to submit your questions here.\n
As you no doubt know by now, Governor Ralph Northam issued a statewide “stay at home” order to protect the health and safety of Virginians and to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. Be assured that VBCPS will nonetheless ensure continuity of operations and learning. To that end, below you will find important information, updates and reminders that I believe will be helpful to you as we head into the next week.\n
School Building Access\n
Our school and administrative buildings remain closed. However, the performance of essential functions is permitted in all schools on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Parents who need to pick up their child’s medication, dental or vision items, or who need to complete enrollments and withdrawals may do so by appointment only on Tuesdays or Wednesdays from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. A photo ID will be required. Should you have this need, please email your principal to arrange for this. Social distancing of 6 feet will be followed during this process. Please do not bring children or come to the school if you are ill.\n
An opportunity for families to either return or pick up nonessential personal belongings will be provided at a later date. This includes clearing out desks and lockers, and returning school-issued uniforms and equipment, personal technology devices, textbooks, instruments and more. Yearbooks, class rings and spring pictures may also be distributed as applicable at this time.\n
Food Services\n
As long as we are able, meals will continue to be offered to all students without charge at any of the 36 schools and five neighborhoods where this service is offered. Children should be present to receive food services. However, should parents need to pick up meals for their children or have a hardship preventing them from accessing meals, they should contact the school administrator via email to arrange for an alternative pickup plan.\n
Meals will be provided on weekdays from 9 a.m. – noon.\n
All school food distribution sites also will be preparing weekend breakfast and lunch meals for students to take home each Friday.\n
We plan to provide food service during Spring Break and will have more on that next week.\n
Technology, Internet Access, Password Issues\n
If you are having problems with a broken Chromebook, we can exchange it for a similar device at any of the schools currently serving as food distribution sites listed above. The complete list is also posted on our website. Please wipe the device with a disinfectant and bring the device and charger to one of those sites between 9 a.m. and noon, Monday through Friday. A VBCPS employee will inventory the broken device and provide a replacement. This service will not be available during Spring Break, but will resume Monday, April 20.\n
If students are having difficulty with their Chromebooks, if you are having issues with your child’s password, or if you need options for internet connectivity, contact the Department of Technology (DoT) Help Desk at (757) 263-1111 between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday through Friday, or fill out this form. Please note that number will not be answered during Spring Break.\n
For those families who have already completed the form or called DoT to request assistance, please know that wireless hotspots have been ordered and are expected to be delivered in the next several days. DoT staff will contact families once these hotspots are available for distribution.\n
Formal Dances\n
Because the Governor’s “stay at home” executive order remains in place until June 10, we unfortunately have to cancel all formal dances this spring, including Ring Dances and Proms. I know how heartbreaking this is for our juniors and seniors, and I feel your frustration. However, the governor’s order necessitates the cancellation of these events. As appropriate and within the next couple of weeks, you will hear more directly from your school about refunds. I know there have been questions about whether or not something can be done later in the summer in lieu of these dances. Nothing has been decided about that at this time. Please note that advertisements and social media posts from companies and individuals offering prom events later in the year are not supported by, endorsed by nor affiliated with Virginia Beach City Public Schools.\n
Graduation Ceremonies\n
As mentioned previously, we remain fully committed to honoring the hard work of our graduating seniors with a ceremony, and our team is looking at several options to do this in both a memorable and safe way – virtually and/or in-person. Our current thinking has us exploring possibilities for ceremonies later in the summer months. Though nothing is official, as the planning pieces come into sharper focus, we will ask the community for feedback on the possible options.\n
Continuity of Learning Shift to New Instruction\n
Our continuity of learning plan will be in effect until April 24, so we ask you to stay the course and continue #VBAlwaysLearning as you have been over the last two weeks. This plan will transition to a more robust instructional model starting April 27.\n
In recent days, the state has put together a Continuity of Learning Taskforce. In order to honor the work of this taskforce and make sure VBCPS’ strategy is aligned with its recommendations, we are waiting for their guidance before sharing the details of our plan. We intend to share those next week, including further details about grading and graduation requirements. In the meantime, it remains important for students to continue to complete work assigned. To review information already shared about this, please visit the FAQs at www.vbschools.com/covid19 .\n
Kindergarten Preregistration and Orientation\n
The VBCPS kindergarten preregistration and orientation that was scheduled for Tuesday, April 28, will be held at a later date, but parents may begin the registration process online as of April 7. Please visit the Online Registration website for details. There is a link within this site that will take you to the Online Registration application.\n
Please be advised when accessing this link:\n\n    
If you currently have a ParentVue account, follow the prompts to submit a new student registration application.\n    
If you don’t remember your ParentVue password or username, click on “More Options” and then “Forgot Password” to enter your email address and further instructions will be sent to you.\n    
If you do not have a ParentVue Account, click on “More Options” and then “Create a New Account,” answer the questions, and a link will be sent to your email address, which will allow you to complete the application.\n\n
 \n
A summer kindergarten registration/orientation will be offered once it is safe to do so. Look for this date to be posted at vbschools.com.\n
Summer School\n
We are exploring all options regarding summer school, including pushing the schedule later into the summer as well as virtual options. More information will follow later this semester.\n
Staying Healthy\n
We encourage your family to follow the CDC guidelines for keeping safe and minimizing the spread of COVID-19. “Social distancing” means staying out of crowded places, avoiding group gatherings, and maintaining a distance of 6 feet from others whenever possible. Medical questions may be directed to the VDH Hotline: 877-275-8343 (877-ASK-VDH3).\n
Again, thank you for your patience and flexibility, and as always, thank you for your support of Virginia Beach City Public Schools.\n
Aaron Spence Ed.D.
\nSuperintendent","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl15_divTabs_4","title":"March 26 Update","content":"
Good evening VBCPS families-\n
Hard to believe that our original two-week closure is about to come to an end. What we had hoped would be a brief pause in the academic year has instead turned into a complete shift in the way we all have to think about our children’s care and education during this health emergency. I know I speak for all here at VBCPS when I say that we are so humbled and grateful for your kindness, patience and encouragement as we have worked to keep students fed and engaged in their learning.\n
Now that Governor Ralph Northam has ordered all Virginia K-12 schools to be closed for the rest of the 2019-2020 academic year, the uncertainty of the length of closure is over, and there’s a certain power in that knowledge. Now we know what we have to do. Of course, there are many, many questions, but now we can move forward. We must take the lessons we’ve learned these past weeks, sustain that momentum and build on it. Our job is to educate this city’s children. That has not changed. How we do it is what is rapidly evolving.\n
I know you’ve got questions about how that evolution will look, and I promise to keep you apprised of our decisions as we keep charting this new territory. I’ve started Deskside Chats, closed- captioned videos that we are sharing every Tuesday and Thursday on YouTube, where I tackle a few questions and provide some updates. Feel free to submit your questions here. We’re also keeping our website current at www.vbschools.com/COVID19.\n
Below, you will find important information, updates and reminders that I believe will be helpful to you as we head into next week.\n
Calendar Changes and Spring Break\n
Last night, the School Board voted to change the 2019-2020 school calendar and extend the third quarter through April 24 in order to give administration time to sort through plans related to instruction during this extended closure. The fourth quarter will now start April 27. The primary reason for this extension of the third quarter is to make sure that we approach instruction and grading in the fourth quarter as thoughtfully as possible and give our teachers, parents and students time to adjust to any changes.\n
To that end, we will be shifting Monday, April 6, to a new schedule where teachers will be participating in professional development each Monday, and students will therefore have access to their teachers from Tuesday through Friday only. This will continue for the remainder of the school year.\n
The Spring Break holiday will stay as is.\n
Continuity of Learning Shift to Virtual Instruction\n
Our continuity of learning plan will be in effect until April 24, so we ask you to stay the course and continue #VBAlwaysLearning as you have been over the last two weeks. This plan will transition to a virtual learning model starting April 27.\n
You may be wondering why we would do this. Why move to a more comprehensive virtual learning model and not just keep doing what we are doing? One of the things we absolutely must do based on federal and state guidance is continue instruction.  At the state level, for the purposes of granting credits and promoting children to the next grade level, we have been given clear guidance from VDOE that students must still show mastery of learning standards in each content area. Students must demonstrate, and we must be able to document, that those objectives have been addressed through instruction. \n
That’s why for now it’s so important that our students continue with learning activities, no matter what grade level they are in. To be clear, all students need to continue to complete and submit coursework assigned by their teachers in order to be able to move on to the next grade level and, for high school students, to get the credits required to graduate. That is also why we also ask families to reach out if they are having difficulty doing this. Please know that we have reiterated and expect that administrators and teachers operate with flexibility and are understanding during this time. We absolutely intend to support our students and families and to ensure that students are able to move forward with their education this year and into the next.\n
More information on this transition to virtual learning is forthcoming.\n
Grading\n
For the third quarter, grades will be calculated based on a student’s grade as of March 13. That said, students also can improve their third quarter grade by completing missing assignments and assessments that would have normally been allowed had the quarter continued with schools open. Details on that will follow from our teachers and principals. \n
Decisions about how grading will be handled for the fourth quarter marking period are forthcoming.\n
Virtual Virginia, AP and IB Testing, and Dual Enrollment\n
Students who are in a Virtual Virginia online course should follow the directions given by their instructor regarding expectations for work and grading.\n
For students in Advanced Placement (AP) classes, the College Board has announced that students will be able to take their AP exams online at home and has provided preparation materials that AP teachers have access to. It is our expectation that AP teachers continue to work with their students to prepare them for these exams. Please reach out to your AP teacher if you have questions.\n
international Baccalaureate (IB) has announced that their exams will be canceled. These students should adhere to the guidelines for learning and work completion being shared with all students.\n
Regarding dual enrollment at Tidewater Community College (TCC), if students are receiving instruction by a VBCPS teacher as part of the dual enrollment program, they should adhere to the guidelines for learning and work completion being shared with all students. However, students in dual enrollment programs who receive instruction from a TCC instructor will continue to have graded assignments that need to be completed on the timeline their TCC instructors lay out for them, per TCC requirements.\n
Graduation Requirements\n
We understand our seniors and their parents have questions regarding graduation requirements. The good news is we will have wide flexibility to make sure that our current seniors graduate, as long as they are in the classes they already need to meet standard or advanced diploma requirements, and were on track to graduate as of March 13.  That’s why it’s so important for our seniors to make sure they are working with their teachers during this third quarter to ensure their grades are on track for graduation and that they continue to demonstrate they are learning. Doing so will allow us to grant our seniors the credits needed to graduate. If your child is not on track, we will do everything possible to get them where they need to be so they can graduate with the Class of 2020.\n
Our seniors might also be wondering about how they fulfill all the other graduation requirements, like the financial literacy, CPR or verified credit requirements, if they haven’t already done so. While this information is still evolving, what I want you to know is that we have been given wide latitude by the state to waive these requirements and those that are required by law are likely to be addressed by the General Assembly shortly. Again, I want all  our seniors to know that we are going to do everything we can do to make sure that they will still receive their diploma. Our high school staff will be working with each student and family to make sure they understand their current status and what they need to do to graduate. \n
If you have more questions about graduation requirements, please email your child’s school counselor and/or administrator.\n
Milestone Events\n
Some of the major concerns we are hearing about are the milestone moments in our seniors’ lives. I wish I had better answers for you about things like prom and graduation, but I don’t right now. Until we understand what guidance we might get on large gatherings from the state and the CDC, as well as the timeframe for that, we simply can’t commit to anything.  I can say it is our intention to do something for graduation that is both memorable and safe. We have teams looking at options, and as soon as I hear more, we will share that information.\n
School Building Access\n
Our school and administrative buildings remain closed to the general public. However, to allow for essential school functions to continue, all schools will be open Tuesday and Wednesday beginning March 31. Parents who need to pick up their child’s personal belongings or complete enrollments and withdrawals may do so by appointment only Tuesday or Wednesday from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. Should you have this need, please email your principal to arrange for this. Social distancing of 6 feet will be followed during this process. Please do not bring children or come to the school if you are ill.\n
Medications and Treatment Supplies Pickup\n
A parent (or designated adult verified by note or phone call) may pick up remaining medications and treatment supplies from their child’s school clinic on the following dates: Tuesday and Wednesday beginning March 31 between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m. A photo ID will be required. Social distancing of 6 feet will be followed during this process. Please do not bring children or come to the school if you are ill.\n
Food Services\n
As long as we are able, meals will continue to be offered to all students without charge at the school and neighborhood sites listed below. All students can receive their meals at any of the 36 schools and five neighborhoods where this service is offered. \n
To maintain the safety guidelines recommended by the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), meals are provided using a drive by/pickup model. They are bagged and include both a breakfast and lunch. To maintain proper social distancing, meal bags will be placed on a table at the pickup site and our servers will step back so that you can grab your bags while maintaining a safe distance.\n
Children must be present to receive food services. Meals will be provided on weekdays from 9 a.m. – noon.\n
Technology, Internet Access and Password Issues\n
If you are having problems with a broken Chromebook, we can exchange it for a similar device at any of the schools currently serving as food distribution sites. The complete list is also posted on our website. Please wipe the device with a disinfectant and bring the device and charger to one of those sites between 9 a.m. and noon, Monday through Friday. A VBCPS employee will inventory the broken device and provide a replacement. \n
If students are having difficulty with their Chromebooks, or if you need options for internet connectivity, contact the Department of Technology (DoT) Help Desk at (757) 263-1111 between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday through Friday, or fill out this form.\n
For those families who have already completed the form or called DoT to request assistance, please know that wireless hotspots have been ordered and are expected to be delivered in the next several days. DoT staff will contact families once these hotspots are available for distribution.\n
If you are having issues with your student’s password, please call the Department of Technology (DoT) Help Desk at (757) 263-1111 between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday through Friday for assistance.\n
Please note this phone number will not be answered during Spring Break.\n
Enrollment and Kindergarten Registration\n
If you need to enroll your student for the current school year, please call our help line at (757) 263-1111 between 8 a.m. and 4 p.m. Monday through Friday, and we will get you to the right person to help you. Please note this phone number will not be answered during Spring Break. If you need to enroll your child for the 2020-21 school year, including a rising kindergarten student, please click on this LINK to begin the registration process online and a member of your child’s zoned school will follow-up with you when our schools reopen.\n\n
Resources\n
We continue to add information to our vbschools.com/COVID19 website, including resources around Social and Emotional Learning. Here are a couple of great reads to get you started:\n
Manage Anxiety and Stress\n
How To Prepare for Extended School Closure and Not Lose Your Mind\n
Staying Healthy\n
We encourage your family to follow the CDC guidelines for keeping safe and minimizing the spread of COVID-19. “Social distancing” means staying out of crowded places, avoiding group gatherings, and maintaining a distance of 6 feet from others whenever possible. Medical questions may be directed to the VDH Hotline: 877-275-8343 (877-ASK-VDH3).\n
Again, thank you for your patience and flexibility, and as always, thank you for your support of Virginia Beach City Public Schools.\n
Aaron Spence Ed.D.
\nSuperintendent\n","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,
                        propPaneId: 'paneId', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propTitle: 'title', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propActive: 'active', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propDisabled: 'disabled', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        propContent: 'content', // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        tabMode : tabM,
                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });
